nexttext:
The
Leibniz cohomology of ${\mathfrak g}$ with coefficients in $V$ is the
cohomology of the cochain complex
$C^k({\mathfrak g},V)={\mathrm{Hom}}(\otimes^k{\mathfrak g},V), (k\geq0)$ with the
coboundary operator $\partial:C^k({\mathfrak g},V)\longrightarrow
C^{k+1}({\mathfrak g},V)$ defined by
\begin{eqnarray}
\nonumber\partial
c^k(x_1,\dots,x_{k+1})&=&\sum_{i=1}^k(-1)^{i+1}l_{x_i}(c^k(x_1,\dots,\widehat{x_i},\dots,x_{k+1}))
+(-1)^{k+1}r_{x_{k+1}}(c^k(x_1,\dots,x_k))\\
\label{formulapartial}&&+\sum_{1\leq i<j\leq
k+1}(-1)^ic^k(x_1,\dots,\widehat{x_i},\dots,x_{j-1},[x_i,x_j]_{\mathfrak g},x_{j+1},\dots,x_{k+1}).
\end{eqnarray}

We  denote by ${\mathrm{Der}}^L({\mathfrak g})$ and ${\mathrm{Der}}^R({\mathfrak g})$ the set of left derivations and the set of right derivations of ${\mathfrak g}$ respectively:
\begin{eqnarray*}
{\mathrm{Der}}^L({\mathfrak g})&=&\{D\in {\mathfrak {gl}}({\mathfrak g})\vert D[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}=[Dx,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}+[x,Dy]_{{\mathfrak g}},\forall x,y\in {\mathfrak g}\},\\
 {\mathrm{Der}}^R({\mathfrak g})&=&\{D\in {\mathfrak {gl}}({\mathfrak g})\vert D[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}=[x,Dy]_{{\mathfrak g}}-[y,Dx]_{{\mathfrak g}},\forall x,y\in {\mathfrak g}\}.
 \end{eqnarray*}
It is easy to see that for all $x\in{\mathfrak g}$, ${\mathrm{ad}}^L_x:{\mathfrak g}\longrightarrow{\mathfrak g}$, which is given by ${\mathrm{ad}}^L_x(y)=[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}$, is a left derivation; ${\mathrm{ad}}^R_x:{\mathfrak g}\longrightarrow{\mathfrak g}$, which is given by ${\mathrm{ad}}^R_x(y)=[y,x]_{{\mathfrak g}}$, is a right derivation.

\begin{lem}\label{LtoCC}
If $x\in{\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak g})$,    then for all $D^L\in{\mathrm{Der}}^L({\mathfrak g})$, we have $D^Lx\in{\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak g})$.
\end{lem}
{\noindent{\bf Proof.}\ } It follows from

we obtain that
${l_xr_y}-r_{[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}}+r_yr_x={\mathrm{ad}}^R_{\omega(x,y)}.$
Combining with \eqref{rep2}, we deduce that \eqref{Left Cen2} holds.

Conversely, if \eqref{l Der}-\eqref{cocycle} hold, it is straightforward to see that $({\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h},[\cdot,\cdot]_{(l,r,\omega)})$ is a Leibniz algebra. The proof is finished.
{\hfill ~\vrule height6pt width6pt depth0pt}\vspace{3mm}



Note that \eqref{l Der} means that $l_x\in {\mathrm{Der}}^L({\mathfrak h})$, and \eqref{r Der} means that $r_x\in {\mathrm{Der}}^R({\mathfrak h})$.

\begin{defi}\label{2cocyle}
A non-abelian $2$-cocycle on ${\mathfrak g}$ with values in ${\mathfrak h}$ is a triple $(l,r,\omega)$ of linear maps $l:{\mathfrak g}\rightarrow {\mathrm{Der}}^L({\mathfrak h}),~~r:{\mathfrak g}\rightarrow {\mathrm{Der}}^R({\mathfrak h})$ and $\omega:{\mathfrak g}\otimes{\mathfrak g}\rightarrow {\mathfrak h}$ satisfying Eqs. \eqref{Left Cen1}-\eqref{cocycle}.
We denote by $Z^2({\mathfrak g},{\mathfrak h})$ the set of non-abelian $2$-cocycles.

Two $2$-cocycles $(l^1,r^1,\omega^1)$ and $(l^2,r^2,\omega^2)$ are equivalent, \emptycomment{$(l^1,r^1,\omega^1)\stackrel{\varphi}\sim(l^2,r^2,\omega^2)$,} if there exists a linear map $\varphi:{\mathfrak g}\rightarrow{\mathfrak h}$ such that  for all $x,y\in{\mathfrak g}$, the following equalities hold:
\begin{eqnarray}
l^1_x-l^2_x&=&{\mathrm{ad}}^L_{\varphi(x)},\label{cohomology 1}\\
r^1_x-r^2_x&=&{\mathrm{ad}}^R_{\varphi(x)},\label{cohomology 2}\\
\omega^1(x,y)-\omega^2(x,y)&=&l^2_x\varphi(y)+r^2_y\varphi(x)+[\varphi(x),\varphi(y)]_{{\mathfrak h}}-\varphi([x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}})\label{cohomology 3}.
\end{eqnarray}

The second non-abelian cohomology $H^2({\mathfrak g},{\mathfrak h})$ is the quotient of $Z^2({\mathfrak g},{\mathfrak h})$ by the above equivalence relation.
\end{defi}



\begin{thm}\label{classification}
Let $({\mathfrak g},[\cdot,\cdot]_{\mathfrak g})$ and $({\mathfrak h},[\cdot,\cdot]_{\mathfrak h})$ be Leibniz algebras. Then non-abelian extensions of ${\mathfrak g}$ by ${\mathfrak h}$ are classified by the second non-abelian cohomology $H^2({\mathfrak g},{\mathfrak h})$.
\end{thm}
{\noindent{\bf Proof.}\ } Let $\hat{{\mathfrak g}}$ be a non-abelian extension of ${\mathfrak g}$ by ${\mathfrak h}$. By choosing a splitting $\sigma_1:{\mathfrak g}\longrightarrow\hat{{\mathfrak g}}$, we obtain a 2-cocycle $(l^1,r^1,\omega^1)$.  First we show that the cohomological class of $(l^1,r^1,\omega^1)$ does not depend on the choice of splittings. In fact,
let $\sigma_1$ and $\sigma_2$ be two different splittings. Define $\varphi:{\mathfrak g}\longrightarrow{\mathfrak h}$ by $\varphi(x):=\sigma_1(x)-\sigma_2(x)$.
 By $l^j_x(\beta)=[\sigma_j(x),\beta]_{\hat{{\mathfrak g}}}$ and $r^j_y(\alpha)=[\alpha,\sigma_j(y)]_{\hat{{\mathfrak g}}},~~j=1,2$, it is obvious that    $(\ref{cohomology 1})$ and $(\ref{cohomology 2})$ hold.
 Furthermore, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
\omega^1(x,y)&=&[\sigma_1(x),\sigma_1(y)]_{\hat{{\mathfrak g}}}-\sigma_1[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}\\
&=&[\sigma_2(x)+\varphi(x),\sigma_2(y)+\varphi(y)]_{\hat{{\mathfrak g}}}-\sigma_2[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}-\varphi([x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}})\\
&=&[\sigma_2(x),\sigma_2(y)]_{\hat{{\mathfrak g}}}+[\sigma_2(x),\varphi(y)]_{\hat{{\mathfrak g}}}+[\varphi(x),\sigma_2(y)]_{\hat{{\mathfrak g}}}+[\varphi(x),\varphi(y)]_{{\mathfrak h}}-\sigma_2[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}-\varphi[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}\\
&=&\sigma_2[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}+\omega^2(x,y)+l^2_x\varphi(y)+r^2_y\varphi(x)+[\varphi(x),\varphi(y)]_{{\mathfrak h}}-\sigma_2[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}-\varphi([x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}})\\
&=&\omega^2(x,y)+l^2_x\varphi(y)+r^2_y\varphi(x)+[\varphi(x),\varphi(y)]_{{\mathfrak h}}-\varphi([x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}),
\end{eqnarray*}
which implies that $(\ref{cohomology 3})$ holds. Thus, $(l^1,r^1,\omega^1)$ and $(l^2,r^2,\omega^2)$  are in the same cohomological class.


Now we go on to prove that isomorphic extensions give rise to the same element in $H^2({\mathfrak g},{\mathfrak h})$. Assume that $\hat{{\mathfrak g}_1}$ and $\hat{{\mathfrak g}_2}$ are isomorphic

  \eqref{diagram1}. Assume that $\sigma_2:{\mathfrak g}\longrightarrow\hat{{\mathfrak g}_2}$ and $\sigma_1:{\mathfrak g}\longrightarrow \hat{{\mathfrak g}_1}$ are two splittings.
Define  $\sigma'_2:{\mathfrak g}\longrightarrow\hat{{\mathfrak g}_2}$ by $\sigma'_2=\theta^{-1}\circ \sigma_1$. Since ${\mathbbm{p}}_1\circ\theta={\mathbbm{p}}_2$, we have

\section{Another approach to non-abelian extensions of Leibniz algebras }\label{Leib20ext}





The notion of strongly homotopy (sh) Leibniz algebras, or
$Lod_\infty$-algebras was introduced in \cite{livernet}, see also $\cite{ammardefiLeibnizalgebra,UchinoshL}$ for more details. In \cite{Leibniz2al}, the authors introduced the notion of a Leibniz 2-algebra, which is the categorification of a Leibniz algebra, and prove that the category of Leibniz 2-algebras and the category of 2-term $Lod_\infty$-algebras are equivalent.

By Proposition \ref{pro:subalgebra}, Condition (d) holds naturally.



For all $(D^L_1,D^R_1),(D^L_2,D^R_2)\in \Pi({\mathfrak h})$,  we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
l_2(\alpha,l_2((D^L_1,D^R_1),(D^L_2,D^R_2)))-l_2(l_2(\alpha,(D^L_1,D^R_1)),(D^L_2,D^R_2))-l_2((D^L_1,D^R_1),l_2(\alpha,(D^L_2,D^R_2)))\\
=[D^L_1,D^R_2]\alpha-D^R_2D^R_1\alpha-D^L_1D^R_2\alpha
=-D^R_2(D_1^L\alpha+D_1^R\alpha)=0,
\end{eqnarray*}
which implies that Condition (${\rm e_1}$) in Definition \ref{defi:2leibniz} holds.

Similarly, Conditions (${\rm e_2}$) and (${\rm e_3}$) also hold. Since $l_3=0$, Condition (f) holds naturally. The proof is finished.
{\hfill ~\vrule height6pt width6pt depth0pt}\vspace{3mm}

when ${\mathfrak h}$ is a Lie algebra, there is a strict Lie 2-algebra $({\mathfrak h},{\mathrm{Der}}({\mathfrak h}),{\mathrm{ad}},l_2)$, where ${\mathrm{Der}}({\mathfrak h})$ is the set of derivations of ${\mathfrak h}$, and $l_2$ is given by

\alpha,({\mathrm{ad}}^{L}_{\beta},{\mathrm{ad}}^{R}_{\beta}))=[\alpha,\beta]_{%
\mathfrak{h}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>l</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>ad</mi><mi>α</mi><mi>L</mi></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>ad</mi><mi>α</mi><mi>R</mi></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>β</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>l</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>ad</mi><mi>β</mi><mi>L</mi></msubsup><mo>,</mo><msubsup><mi>ad</mi><mi>β</mi><mi>R</mi></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>β</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mi>𝔥</mi></msub></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

Similarly, Conditions (${\rm e_2}$) and (${\rm e_3}$) also hold. Since $l_3=0$, Condition (f) holds naturally. The proof is finished.

{\noindent{\bf Proof.}\ } Let $\hat{{\mathfrak g}}=({\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h},[\cdot,\cdot]_{(l,r,\omega)})$ be a non-abelian extension of ${\mathfrak g}$ by ${\mathfrak h}$ with ${\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak h})={\mathrm{Z}}(\hat{{\mathfrak g}})\cap {\mathfrak h}$.
Then, $l,r,\omega$ satisfy Eqs. \eqref{l Der}-\eqref{cocycle}. By $(\ref{l Der})$ and $(\ref{r Der})$, we have $l_x\in{\mathrm{Der}}^L({\mathfrak g})$ and $r_x\in{\mathrm{Der}}^R({\mathfrak g})$.
By $(\ref{Left Cen1})$ and $(\ref{Left Cen2})$, we have $l_x(\alpha)+r_x(\alpha)\in {\mathrm{Z}}(\hat{{\mathfrak g}})\cap{\mathfrak h}\subset {\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak h})$, which implies that $f_0(x)(\alpha)\in{\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak h})$, for all $\alpha\in {\mathfrak h}$. Furthermore, it is obvious that    $r_x({\mathrm{Z}}(\hat{{\mathfrak g}})\cap{\mathfrak h})=0$. By the condition
${\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak h})={\mathrm{Z}}(\hat{{\mathfrak g}})\cap {\mathfrak h}$, we get $r_x({\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak h}))=0$. Thus, we deduce that $f_0(x)\in\Xi({\mathfrak h})$. Furthermore, by $(\ref{rep1})$ and $(\ref{rep2})$, we  get
\begin{eqnarray*}
l_2(f_0(x),f_0(y))-f_0([x,y]_{\mathfrak g})&=&([l_x,l_y]-l_{[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}},[l_x,r_y]-r_{[x,y]_{{\mathfrak g}}})=({\mathrm{ad}}^L_{\omega(x,y)},{\mathrm{ad}}^R_{\omega(x,y)})\\
&=&({\mathrm{ad}}^L,{\mathrm{ad}}^R)f_2(x,y).
\end{eqnarray*}
At last, by $(\ref{cocycle})$, we deduce that \eqref{eqn:DGLA morphism c 2} holds. Thus, $(f_0,f_1,f_2)$ is a morphism from ${\mathfrak g}$ to the Leibniz 2-algebra $({\mathfrak h},\Xi({\mathfrak h}),({\mathrm{ad}}^L,{\mathrm{ad}}^R),l_2)$.

Conversely,  by the fact that $(f_0,f_1,f_2)$ is a morphism from ${\mathfrak g}$ to  $({\mathfrak h},\Xi({\mathfrak h}),({\mathrm{ad}}^L,{\mathrm{ad}}^R),l_2)$, it is straightforward to deduce that Eqs.
$(\ref{l Der})$-$(\ref{cocycle})$ hold. Furthermore, for all $\alpha\in{\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak h})$, by the fact that $r_y{\mathrm{Z}}({\mathfrak h})=0$, we have

Conversely, we assume $f^1=(f^1_0,f^1_1,f^1_2)\stackrel{\varphi}\sim f^2=(f^2_0,f^2_1,f^2_2)$. Let $l^j_x={\mathrm{Pr}}_Lf^j_0(x)$ and $r^j_x={\mathrm{Pr}}_R{f^j}_0(x),~~j=1,2$. Then by equation $(\ref{2-mor1})$ of Definition  $\ref{2-mor}$, one has
\begin{eqnarray*}
l^1_x-l^2_x&=&{\mathrm{ad}}^L_{\varphi(x)},\\
r^1_x-r^2x&=&{\mathrm{ad}}^R_{\varphi(x)}.
\end{eqnarray*}
And by equation $(\ref{2-mor3})$ of Definition  $\ref{2-mor}$, one also has

nexttext: Let $({\mathfrak g},[\cdot,\cdot]_{\mathfrak g})$ and $({\mathfrak h},[\cdot,\cdot]_{\mathfrak h})$ be two Leibniz algebras. Let ${\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h}$ be the Leibniz algebra direct sum of   ${\mathfrak g}$ and ${\mathfrak h}$, where the bracket is defined by  $[x+\alpha,y+\beta]=[x,y]_{\mathfrak g}+[\alpha,\beta]_{\mathfrak h}$. Then there is DGLA  $(C({\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h},{\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h}), [\cdot,\cdot]_{C},\overline{\partial})$, where $\partial $ is the coboundary operator for the  Leibniz algebra ${\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h}$ with the coefficients in the adjoint representation. It is straightforward to see that $(C({\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h}, {\mathfrak h}), [\cdot,\cdot]_{C},\overline{\partial})$ is a sub-DGLA. Define $C^k_>({\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h},{\mathfrak h})\subset C^k({\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h},{\mathfrak h})$ by

For all $e_i=x_i+\alpha_i\in{\mathfrak g}\oplus{\mathfrak h}$, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
[c,\varphi]_C(e_1,e_2)&=&[\omega+r+l,\varphi]_{C}(e_1,e_2)
= l_{x_1}\varphi(x_2)+r_{x_2}\varphi(x_1),\\
\partial\varphi(e_1,e_2)&=&{[\alpha_1,\varphi(x_2)]}_{{\mathfrak h}}+{[\varphi(x_1),\alpha_2]}_{{\mathfrak h}}-\varphi([x_1,x_2]_{\mathfrak g}),\\
{[\partial\varphi,\varphi]}_{C}(e_1,e_2)&=&2{[\varphi(x_1),\varphi(x_2)]}_{{\mathfrak h}}.
\end{eqnarray*}
Therefore, we have
